dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Informal and conversational tech news discussion

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so we're diving into this, uh, really interesting and kinda ongoing saga between Apple and this company called Grayshift. It's like a never-ending cat-and-mouse game, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so we're diving into this, uh, really interesting and kinda ongoing saga between Apple and this company called Grayshift. It's like a never-ending cat and mouse game, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. So, for those who, like, might not remember, Grayshift popped up a few years ago. Their big thing was this GrayKey tech, promising governments they could, uh, crack passcodes on iPhones, even the latest models, like the iPhone X back then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. So, for those who, like, might not remember, Grayshift popped up a few years ago. Their big thing was this GrayKey tech, promising governments they could, uh, crack passcodes on iPhones, even the latest models, like the iPhone X back then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Uncloaked by Forbes in March, Atlanta-based Grayshift promised governments its GrayKey tech could crack the passcodes of the latest iOS models, right up to the iPhone X.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, you know, Apple, being Apple, a company known for, um, its *security failures* – I mean, privacy, right? – they really started investing in privacy concerns, putting up these barriers for Grayshift to jump over.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, you know, Apple, being Apple, a company known for, um, its security failures - I mean, privacy, right? - they really started investing in privacy concerns, putting up these barriers for Grayshift to jump over.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From then on, Apple continued to invest in security in earnest, continually putting up barriers for Grayshift to jump over.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and for a while, it seemed like it was working! Grayshift actually started, like, losing contracts. ICE, the Secret Service, they were reportedly pulling out. It looked like Apple was winning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and for a while, it seemed like it was working! Grayshift actually started, like, losing contracts. I C E, the Secret Service, they were reportedly pulling out. It looked like Apple was winning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Grayshift continued to grow, however, securing contracts with Immigration and Customs Enforcement, and the Secret Service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But then, uh, Forbes recently dropped this bombshell, saying GrayKey can *still* break passcodes on *any* iPhone running iOS 12 or above.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But then, uh, Forbes recently dropped this bombshell, saying GrayKey can still break passcodes on any iPhone running iOS twelve or above.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Multiple sources familiar with the GrayKey tech tell Forbes the device can no longer break the passcodes of any iPhone running iOS 12 or above.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, really? So, like, all those efforts by Apple... [interrupts] weren't enough?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? So, like, all those efforts by Apple... weren't enough?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently not for everyone. Sources familiar with the tech say GrayKey can perform a "full extraction" on those devices. That means, like, police using the tool would get access to *all* files, all metadata, folder structures, the works.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently not for everyone. Sources familiar with the tech say GrayKey can perform a full extraction on those devices. That means, like, police using the tool would get access to all files, all metadata, folder structures, the works.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On those devices, GrayKey can only do whats called a partial extraction, sources from the forensic community said. That means police using the tool can only draw out unencrypted files and some metadata, such as file sizes and folder structures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, it's not just a passcode. It's like, the whole enchilada. And I remember GrayKey traditionally used, uh, brute-forcing techniques, didn't it? Just guessing passcodes until it worked, somehow getting around Apple's protections against repeated guesses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, it's not just a passcode. It's like, the whole enchilada. And I remember GrayKey traditionally used, uh, brute-forcing techniques, didn't it? Just guessing passcodes until it worked, somehow getting around Apple's protections against repeated guesses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Previously, GrayKey used brute forcing techniques to guess passcodes and had found a way to get around Apples protections preventing such repeat guesses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the success, apparently, has continued. Captain John Sherwin from the Rochester Police Department in Minnesota, he actually said, and I'm quoting here, about the claim iOS 12 was preventing GrayKey from unlocking iPhones: "That's a completely false assessment as to what we have experienced."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the success, apparently, has continued. Captain John Sherwin from the Rochester Police Department in Minnesota, he actually said, and I'm quoting here, about the claim iOS twelve was preventing GrayKey from unlocking iPhones: That's a completely false assessment as to what we have experienced.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Police officer Captain John Sherwin of the Rochester Police Department in Minnesota said of the claim iOS 12 was preventing GrayKey from unlocking iPhones: 'Thats a fairly accurate assessment as to what we have experienced.'

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, it's still working for them. But I thought, uh, you know, there was talk about GrayShift struggling now? Like, Apple *was* winning in some ways?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, it's still working for them. But I thought, uh, you know, there was talk about GrayShift struggling now? Like, Apple was winning in some ways?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, this is where it gets a little, um, mysterious. Forbes mentions a "mysterious success" where Apple *has* locked Grayshift out in some capacity, but experts, like Vladimir Katalov from Elcomsoft, he's stumped. He has "no idea" how Apple's achieving *that* part of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, this is where it gets a little, um, mysterious. Forbes mentions a mysterious success where Apple has locked Grayshift out in some capacity, but experts, like Vladimir Katalov from Elcomsoft, he's stumped. He has no idea how Apple's achieving that part of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A mystery fix Though its clear Apple has locked GrayShift out, no one actually knows just how the iPhone maker has done it. Vladimir Katalov, chief of forensic tech provider Elcomsoft, has repeatedly uncovered weaknesses in Apple technology. But he was stumped too. 'No idea.'

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] So, it's almost like a partial victory for Apple? Because Wired reported that, uh, some UK police agencies aren't using GrayKeys anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's almost like a partial victory for Apple? Because Wired reported that, uh, some U K police agencies aren't using GrayKeys anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wiredrevealed last week that a number of U.K. police agencies are now using GrayKeys.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. So Grayshift is "struggling" and "gone local" in some areas, but for others, the tech is still, uh, fully functional on current iOS versions. It's just... this constant back and forth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. So Grayshift is struggling and gone local in some areas, but for others, the tech is still, uh, fully functional on current iOS versions. It's just... this constant back and forth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Multiple sources familiar with the GrayKey tech tell Forbes the device can no longer break the passcodes of any iPhone running iOS 12 or above. ... Wiredrevealed last week that a number of U.K. police agencies are now using GrayKeys.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So the takeaway here is that, um, even with Apple's best efforts, device security is still, like, an evolving target. There's no permanent fix.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the takeaway here is that, um, even with Apple's best efforts, device security is still, like, an evolving target. There's no permanent fix.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. The cycle, as Captain Sherwin put it, continues. No one's, uh, building a truly better mousetrap, whether it's Apple or someone trying to defeat device security. It just keeps going.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. The cycle, as Captain Sherwin put it, continues. No one's, uh, building a truly better mousetrap, whether it's Apple or someone trying to defeat device security. It just keeps going.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Someone is always building a better mousetrap, whether its Apple or someone trying to defeat device security.
